clinical_study.brief_title: Alive & Thrive Evaluation in Burkina Faso
clinical_study.official_title: Alive & Thrive Evaluation in Burkina Faso

lead_sponsor.agency: London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine

clinical_study.source: London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine

brief_summary.textblock:
The time between birth and age 24 months provides a unique opportunity to impact the long-term health and development of children through improved infant and young child feeding practices. In Burkina Faso, the prevalence of exclusive breastfeeding is currently around 25% in infants younger than six months.
The purpose of this study is to evaluate whether the Alive & Thrive intervention package, consisting of interpersonal counselling and community mobilisation activities, can increase the exclusive breastfeeding rate among infants younger than six months to at least 50% using a cluster randomised design.

primary_outcome.measure: Exclusive breastfeeding on the day preceding the interview as assessed by cross sectional survey
primary_outcome.time_frame: Infants up to 6 months in a cross-sectional endline survey scheduled for April - July 2017
primary_outcome.description: The proportion of infants aged less than 6 months who were exclusively breastfed on the day preceding the interview.

secondary_outcome.measure: Breastfeeding within 1 hour of birth as assessed by cross sectional survey
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Infants up to 6 months in a cross-sectional endline survey scheduled for April - July 2017
secondary_outcome.description: The proportion of newborns aged less than 6 months who were breastfed within 1 hour of birth.

secondary_outcome.measure: Colostrum given as assessed by cross sectional survey
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Infants up to 6 months in a cross-sectional endline survey scheduled for April - July 2017
secondary_outcome.description: The proportion of newborns aged less than 6 months who were given colostrum.

secondary_outcome.measure: Pre-lacteal feeds as assessed by cross sectional survey
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Infants up to 6 months in a cross-sectional endline survey scheduled for April - July 2017
secondary_outcome.description: The proportion of newborns aged less than 6 months who received no pre-lacteal feeds before breastfeeding was established

secondary_outcome.measure: Semi-solid, solid or soft foods consumed in the previous day as assessed by cross sectional survey
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Infants age 6-8 months in a cross-sectional endline survey scheduled for April - July 2017
secondary_outcome.description: The proportion of infants age 6 to 8 months who received semi-solid, solid or soft foods in the previous day.

secondary_outcome.measure: Minimum acceptable diet (apart from breast milk) on the day preceding interview as assessed by cross sectional survey
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Infants age 6-11.9 months in a cross-sectional endline survey scheduled for April - July 2017
secondary_outcome.description: The proportion of infants aged 6 to 11.9 months who received a minimum acceptable diet (apart from breast milk) on the day preceding interview.

secondary_outcome.measure: Dietary diversity as assessed by cross sectional survey
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Infants age 6-11.9 months in a cross-sectional endline survey scheduled for April - July 2017
secondary_outcome.description: Dietary diversity among infants age 6 to 11.9 months.

secondary_outcome.measure: Breast milk on the day preceding the interview as assessed by cross sectional survey
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Infants age 6-11.9 months in a cross-sectional endline survey scheduled for April - July 2017
secondary_outcome.description: The proportion of children aged 6 to 11.9 months who were fed breast milk on the day preceding the interview.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mother's accurate knowledge of good breastfeeding practice as assessed by cross sectional survey
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Mothers of infants aged up to 12 months in a cross-sectional endline survey scheduled for April - July 2017
secondary_outcome.description: Mother's accurate knowledge of: Optimal timing of breastfeeding initiation Optimal duration of exclusive breastfeeding Benefits of optimal breastfeeding practices for the infant Solutions to common difficulties, for example engorgement, cracked and sore nipples Optimal timing to introduce complementary feeding Optimal dietary diversity and frequency of complementary feeding up to 12 months

secondary_outcome.measure: Mother's self-reported breastfeeding practices as assessed by cross sectional survey
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Mothers of infants aged up to 12 months in a cross-sectional endline survey scheduled for April - July 2017
secondary_outcome.description: Mother's self-reported breastfeeding practices, including asking her if she experiences any barriers or difficulties with breastfeeding such as engorgement, cracked and sore nipples, or breastfeeding when working outside of the home.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mother's perceptions and beliefs surrounding breastfeeding
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Mothers of infants aged up to 12 months in a cross-sectional endline survey scheduled for April - July 2017
secondary_outcome.description: Mother's perceptions and beliefs about breastfeeding (qualitative component).

secondary_outcome.measure: Knowledge, beliefs and perceptions surrounding breastfeeding of family members
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Family members of infants aged up to 12 months in a cross-sectional endline survey scheduled for April - July 2017
secondary_outcome.description: Knowledge, beliefs and perceptions of family members, such as mothers or mothers in law, community opinion leaders towards optimal infant and child feeding practices (qualitative component).

intervention.intervention_name: A&T infant and young child feeding intervention
intervention.description: Interpersonal communication delivered by community workers and volunteers during home visits and at monthly mother's group meetings to: Increase mother's knowledge about optimal breastfeeding and its benefits Increase mother's self-efficacy related to breastfeeding Improve mother's perceptions about social norms relating to breastfeeding Community mobilisation activities to: - Raise awareness of the benefits of optimal breastfeeding among opinion leaders, and family members, and increase the support they provide to breastfeeding mothers Enhanced training of government health workers in infant and young child feeding to: Improve their ability to support mothers and provide timely information about infant feeding

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Gives informed consent
- Being aged from 15 to 49 years old (women of reproductive age)
- Has at least one infant less than 12 months old who is currently alive and lives with her.
